newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian Sberbank to pay 1996 dividends.
newsitem.headline: Russian Sberbank to pay 1996 dividends.

text.p: Shareholders of Russia's biggest bank, Sberbank, decided on Friday to pay 30,000 roubles in dividend per 50,000 rouble ordinary share for 1996 and 800 roubles per 1,000 rouble preferred share, the bank said.
"These are the highest dividend figures paid by Russian commercial banks," Sberbank President Andrei Kazmin told a news conference.
In 1995, Sberegatelny Bank Rossiiskoi Federatsii paid 35,000 roubles on ordinary shares and 2,500 roubles on the preferred.
Kazmin also said the shareholders' meeting approved raising paid up capital to one trillion roubles from the current 700.1 billion roubles by issuing new shares.
He said the increase would be done in several issues of ordinary shares and the first issue would amount to 50 billion roubles.
The Central Bank owns 50 percent plus one share in Sberbank, which is the biggest operator in the government securities market. Other major shareholders are Tokobank and Vneshtorgbank Rossii.
Sberbank dominates Russia's individuals' deposit market.
At 13.15 GMT Sberbank was traded at $142.5 after $138.7 at Thursday's close on the Russian Trading System.
